questions.text: A patient is undergoing orthopedic surgery. Which of the following first-generation cephalosporins can you use for surgical prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
The first-generation cephalosporin indicated for surgical prophylaxis is Cefazolin. It is the preferred agent for surgical prophylaxis when skin flora is the likely pathogen.

Cephalexin, cefadroxil, and cephradine are first-generation oral cephalosporins.

questions.text: In comparison with first-generation cephalosporins, second-generation cephalosporins have which of the following properties?

choices.text: Greater activity against gram positive bacteria
Lesser activity against gram positive bacteria

questions.solution:
Second-generation cephalosporins have lesser activity against gram-positive bacteria when compared with first-generation cephalosporins.

Properties of second-generation cephalosporins, when compared to first-generation cephalosporins, are:

  • Lesser activity against gram-positive bacteria
  • Broader gram-negative activity against Hemophilus species, indole-positive Proteus, and Klebsiella species
  • Anaerobes like B.fragilis are susceptible to second-generation cephalosporins like cefoxitin and cefotetan but not first-generation cephalosporins

questions.text: Cephalosporins are not useful in which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Ampicillin is the drug of choice for listeriosis, which is caused by Listeria monocytogenes, and cephalosporins are not useful in treating this condition.

Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, which is considered as a treatment of choice for gonorrhea and severe forms of Lyme disease.

Cefoperazone and ceftazidime are third-generation cephalosporins that have clinically significant activity against Pseudomonas.

Cephalosporins Therapeutic uses
First-generation
  • Skin and soft tissue infections
  • Serious infections due to MSSA
  • Perioperative surgical prophylaxis
Second generation
  • Upper respiratory tract infections (sinusitis, otitis media)
  • Cefoxitin/cefotetan - gynecologic infections, perioperative surgical prophylaxis
Third generation
  • Community-acquired pneumonia, meningitis, urinary tract infections
  • Streptococcal endocarditis
  • Gonorrhea
  • Severe Lyme disease

questions.text: The pus culture and sensitivity report of a hospitalized patient with diabetic ulcer is positive for pseudomonas. Which of the following cephalosporins can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
The drug that can be used in this patient is Ceftazidime, which is a third-generation parenteral cephalosporin having significant anti-pseudomonal action.

Cefpodoxime proxetil is a third-generation oral cephalosporin. It does not have significant antipseudomonal action.

Cephradine and cefotetan are first and second-generation cephalosporins with no antipseudomonal action.

Antipseudomonal cell wall synthesis inhibitors are:

  • Cephalosporins: 
    • Third generation - Ceftazidime, Cefoperazone
    • Fourth generation - Cefepime and cefpirome. They are also used against enterobacter
    • Fifth generation - Ceftolozane
  • Extended-spectrum penicillins:
    • Carboxypenicillins - carbenicillin, ticarcillin 
    • Ureidopenicillins - piperacillin, mezlocillin

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cefepime is false?

choices.text: Dose should be reduced in renal failure

questions.solution:
Cefepime, which is a fourth-generation cephalosporin, has good activity against Pseudomonas, Enterobacter, and S. aureus, but not against MRSA. It is effective in serious infections like hospital-acquired pneumonia, septicemia and febrile neutropenia. 

Cefepime is excreted primarily through kidneys and dose reduction is necessary for renal failure. Encephalopathy and non-convulsive status epilepticus have been reported with the use of cefepime.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with a discharging wound post-operatively. Cultures reveal infection with MRSA. Which of the following cephalosporins can be used for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ceftaroline is the cephalosporin that is indicated for MRSA infections and hence can be used in this patient. It is considered as anti-MRSA cephalosporin and along with ceftobiprole is grouped as fifth-generation cephalosporins.

Ceftaroline has gram-negative and also enhanced gram-positive coverage. It is effective against MRSA and penicillin-resistant S. pneumoniae.

Cefepime and cefpirome are fourth-generation cephalosporins with no significant action on MRSA.

Ceftolozane is a fifth-generation antipseudomonal cephalosporin with no action on MRSA.

questions.text: A patient is to be started on a cephalosporin antibiotic. His serum creatinine levels yesterday at the time of admission was 1.1 mg/dl and now it is 1.5 mg/dl. Which of the following cephalosporins can be started without dose reduction in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of acute kidney injury and the cephalosporin that does not require dose reduction in this patient is cefoperazone.

All cephalosporins are usually excreted by glomerular filtration and tubular secretion. They need a dose reduction in renal failure, except cefpiramide and cefoperazone that have predominant biliary excretion.

Dose reduction is necessary for cefoperazone and cefpiramide in patients with hepatic impairment.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for a patient who presents with an initial episode of Clostridium difficile infection?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the treatment of initial episode of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) is fidaxomicin. It is a macrocyclic antibiotic.

Fidaxomicin is preferred because of its safety profile and higher beneficial effects. But in resource-limited settings where it is not available, vancomycin can be used for the treatment of this condition.

Treatment of Clostridium difficile infection:

  • Fidaxomicin
  • Vancomycin
  • Metronidazole

Vancomycin and fidaxomicin are more effective than metronidazole. All of the above drugs are given orally. 

Loracarbef is a second-generation cephalosporin and is not indicated in pseudomembranous colitis caused by Clostridium difficile.

NOTE:

As per the Infectious Disease Society of America (IDSA) management guidelines 2021, Fidaxomicin is now preferred over Vancomycin for the treatment of initial episode of Clostridium difficile infection. Vancomycin can be used as an alternative drug.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of vancomycin?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of vancomycin is cell wall synthesis inhibition.

The bacterial cell wall has long chains of peptidoglycan and is cross-linked to each other by the action of the enzyme transglycosylase. Vancomycin is a glycopeptide group of antibiotics that binds to the D-alanyl-D-alanine terminus of the synthesized peptidoglycan. This inhibits the transglycosylase enzyme and prevents elongation and cross-linking of peptidoglycan. This leads to the weakening of the cell wall causing lysis.

It exhibits a time-dependant or concentration-independent killing of bacteria. It primarily acts on Gram +ve organisms which are resistant to other antibiotics such as methicillin-resistant staphylococcus and ampicillin resistant enterococci.

Lipoglycopeptides are a new generation of glycopeptide congeners which include telavancin, dalbavancin, and oritavancin. Dalbavancin and Oritovancin are administered as a single intravenous dose for skin and soft-tissue infections.

questions.text:
Oral vancomycin is used in the treatment of :
  1. C. difficile associated diarrhea
  2. Pneumococcal pneumonia
  3. Staphylococcal enterocolitis
  4. Wound infection caused by MRSA
  5. Staphylococcal endocarditis
questions.solution:
Oral vancomycin is used in the treatment of Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea and staphylococcal enterocolitis.

Its oral formulation is not absorbed systemically and hence is used for local action in the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A patient on intravenous vancomycin develops flushing and erythematous lesions. On examination, tachycardia, and hypotension are noted. By what mechanism does vancomycin cause these effects?

choices.text: Direct toxic effect on mast cells

questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts red man syndrome associated with vancomycin. It occurs due to a direct toxic effect on mast cells resulting in the release of histamine.

Red man or red neck syndrome is a non-allergic reaction due to rapid intravenous infusion of vancomycin characterized by: 

  • Flushing
  • Erythematous, urticarial reactions
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension

Slow infusion, prophylactic use of antihistamines can reduce the incidence.

questions.text:
Match the following bacteria with the drug of choice for each.
Bacteria Drug
A. Bacteroides 1. Vancomycin
B. MRSA 2. Metronidazole
C. Hemophilus   3. Meropenem
D. Klebsiella 4. Penicillin
questions.solution:
Vancomycin is the drug of choice for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It should be used only if the organism is resistant to other drugs.

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.

Metronidazole is used in the treatment of the following conditions:

  • Giardiasis
  • Trichomoniasis
  • Amoebiasis
  • Bacterial vaginosis
  • Pseudomembranous colitis

Meropenem is used in infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria like Klebsiella.

Carbapenems are not hydrolyzed by ESBL (extended-spectrum beta-lactamases). Therefore, carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem and ertapenem are resistant to hydrolysis by ESBLs. They are indicated in the treatment of infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria, like Klebsiella and E. coli.

Penicillins like amoxicillin, ampicillin can be used in H. influenzae infections.

questions.text: A patient allergic to penicillin requires antibiotic therapy. Which of the following can you safely prescribe?
questions.solution:
Aztreonam can be safely given to a patient with a history of allergy to penicillin. It is a monobactam group of β-Lactam antibiotics resistant to narrow-spectrum beta-lactamase produced by bacteria.

It lacks cross-sensitivity with the other beta-lactams, except for ceftazidime. It has activity only against gram-negative bacteria. It has no activity against gram-positive bacteria and anaerobes.

questions.text: Which of the following carbapenems has increased risk of causing seizures?
questions.solution:
Imipenem is the carbapenem that is associated with an increased risk of causing seizures, especially when high doses are given to patients with CNS lesions.

Excretion of imipenem is mainly renal and dosage modification is required to avoid seizures in renal failure patients.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about extended-spectrum beta-lactamases?

choices.text: They can hydrolyse penicillins, cephalosporins as well as monobactam
Ambler classification of ESBL is based on amino acid sequence
Third and fourth generation cephalosporins are used for detection of ESBL

questions.solution:
Carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem are resistant to hydrolysis by extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBL) and hence are indicated in the treatment of infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria.

Beta-lactamases are enzymes produced by bacteria that are able to hydrolyze antibiotics and make them ineffective, thus making the bacteria resistant to these antibiotics. They confer resistance against: 

  • Penicillins
  • Cephalosporins
  • Monobactams

Beta lactamases hydrolyze first and second-generation cephalosporins but are ineffective against third and fourth-generation.

Beta lactamases are classified into four categories based on their amino acid sequences, by the Ambler classification. 

ESBLs also hydrolyze third and fourth-generation cephalosporins - cefotaxime, ceftazidime, ceftriaxone and cefepime.

questions.text: Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of imipenem.

Imipenem is rapidly hydrolyzed by the enzyme renal dehydropeptidase. It is administered with cilastatin, a reversible inhibitor of dehydropeptidase to inhibit the breakdown and prolong the action of imipenem.

Meropenem is not hydrolyzed by renal dehydropeptidase. Cilastatin administration is not necessary with meropenem.

The FDA approved Recarbrio (a combination of imipenem-cilastatin and relebactam) to treat hospital-acquired bacterial pneumonia and ventilator-associated bacterial pneumonia in patients ≥18 years. It was previously approved to treat patients with complicated urinary tract infections and complicated intra-abdominal infections who have limited or no alternative treatment options.

questions.text: A patient with a complicated urinary tract infection is put on a newly approved combination of meropenem and a non-suicidal beta-lactamase inhibitor. Identify this drug.
questions.solution:
Vaborbactam is a recently approved non-suicidal beta-lactamase inhibitor. It is indicated in combination with meropenem for complicated urinary tract infections.

Sulbactam, tazobactam and clavulanic acid are suicidal inhibitors of beta-lactamase enzyme.

Suicidal inhibitors are irreversible inhibitors that can permanently inactivate the β-lactamase through secondary chemical reactions in the enzyme active site.
